STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 10, 2024
Jennifer Claire Milliman
Fostering Futures
2008 Hogback RD STE 6
Ann Arbor, MI, 48105-9751
Re: License #: CB810302599
Dear Ms. Milliman:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
9/20/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at 517- 243- 9743.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (c) Dates and places of contacts, names of
persons interviewed, and names of the
interviewers. If children are interviewed,
their last names may not be included in the
report.
One of two special evaluations reviewed included the foster child’s first and last
n ames in the special evaluation report.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
Three of eight foster children case files were reviewed, three were late with the
updated service plan.
2

CPA RULE 400.12418 D e v e l o pment of service plans
• (5) An agency shall involve the child’s parent or
parents in the development of service plans to
enable the parent or parents and foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the parents’ and the
foster parents’ role in assisting the agency the agency in
carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and
review the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent
or parents and foster parents. The agency must inform
the parent or parents and foster parent that the
information in the parent-agency treatment plan and any
other information about the child and the child’s family is
confidential.
Seven of eight foster care files reviewed did not indicate that the parents’ and/or
foster parents were involved in the child’s parent -agency treatment plan. There was
no information on the plan that indicated the agency reviewed the plan with the
parents and/or foster parents.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical Assistance was not requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
3

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period. One CAP submitted was in response to the 2023 renewal
inspection completed on 10/9/2023 and the CAP was approved on 10/11/2023.
The agency was cited for 2 violations.
A special investigation #2023C0000541 was initiated on 6/14/2023. The report
was completed on 7/11/2023, and the CAP was approved on 8/1/2023. The
agency was in violation of rule 400.12409 Education policy. There was no repeat
violation of this rule.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) discussed barriers that impeded the agency last year.
CA reported a supervisor was suddenly dismissed that resulted in another
supervisor having six staff members for a limited time period while hiring a new
supervisor. CA reported this barrier was quickly resolved. Another barrier reported
was worker burn out that caused late case plans. The agency experienced
unexpected case crises that involved workers having to report into the community
to assist with crises situations and not completing their caseload requirements
such as uploading reports, completing reports timely and other responsibilities.
The CA discussed a MiTEAM training that was a communication issue with the
BSC Analyst that was required but the agency was not informed that it was a
required training, so all of the agency staff missed this training. CA reported the
agency is still struggling with the repeat violations from the last audit. CA reported
the agency is correcting this problem and has implemented new interventions
such as the supervisors will generate, print and sign completed reports, give them
to the office manager who will ensure the workers have reports to take to their
next home visits for signatures.
Financial Overview
Reviewed the agency independent auditor’s report dated December 31, 2022, and
2021, and the agency annual financial report. There were no financial concerns
identified.
Staff Interviews
All staff interviewed reported their immediate supervisors and coworkers are very
supportive. They all reported they participate in regular and frequent supervision
meetings and the agency is warm and welcoming. Staff reported they are provided
with training opportunities. However, the staff added they feel the agency needs to
improve upon the inconsistency within the agency because the job is always
changing, and staff are not always aware that something has changed until the
change has already happened and in effect. Staff feel they do not have the chance
to process the change with their team. Staff reported they would change the
4

onboarding process when an employee is hired that include more office
participation among staff/programs and more in person contact involving agency
trainings.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has the space and equipment needed to perform job requirements.
The files are stored securely to prevent unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
10/9/2024

Pinkey Brown Date
